interactions.content:
#### Section 1: Introduction
Organic molecules comprise 99% of what we mean when we say "molecules."
The ability to speak a few words of Organic---as in a language---is thus
profoundly valuable when engineering organic nanostructures. One type of
organic nanostructure is a **polymer**. Polymers are long chains of
atoms, usually made of carbon and a few other elements. This is the
first chapter in a series of three on polymers. Chapter 5 treats
polymers as examples of organic nanostructures (as in vaccine delivery
particles), Chapter 6 treats them as the components of solid objects (as
in a piece of plexiglass), and Chapter 7 covers some examples of
electronic polymers. For a video primer to this chapter, visit

>>>video(https://youtu.be/v_5SYuuiyK4)

Organic structures play a central role in nanoengineering. They comprise
all polymers (including all photoresists used in nanofabrication),
liquid crystals, molecular dyes, and many of the additives used during
the growth of nanocrystals and quantum dots. Moreover, polymers are
found widely in biology and comprise most biological macromolecules:
polypeptides, polysaccharides, and nucleic acids. Almost every drug
molecule is an organic structure. Lucky for us, it is not necessary to
take an entire year of organic chemistry to learn what you need to know
to be an effective nanoengineer. In fact, it's best not to even think of
this material as "organic chemistry." Rather, you can think of it as
*molecular structure and bonding*. It just so happens that most
molecules are made of carbon, hydrogen, nitrogen, oxygen and a few other
supporting players like sulfur and phosphorous, and thus considered
"organic."
Do you have any questions?

"organic."
Do you have any questions?
what are polymers?

Polymers are long chains of atoms, usually made of carbon and a few other elements. They are a type of organic nanostructure. The textbook section you're reading introduces this concept. Would you like to know more about their properties or applications?

#### Section 1: Introduction
Organic molecules comprise 99% of what we mean when we say "molecules."
The ability to speak a few words of Organic---as in a language---is thus
profoundly valuable when engineering organic nanostructures. One type of
organic nanostructure is a **polymer**. Polymers are long chains of
atoms, usually made of carbon and a few other elements. This is the
first chapter in a series of three on polymers. Chapter 5 treats
polymers as examples of organic nanostructures (as in vaccine delivery
particles), Chapter 6 treats them as the components of solid objects (as
in a piece of plexiglass), and Chapter 7 covers some examples of
electronic polymers. For a video primer to this chapter, visit

>>>video(https://youtu.be/v_5SYuuiyK4)

Organic structures play a central role in nanoengineering. They comprise
all polymers (including all photoresists used in nanofabrication),
liquid crystals, molecular dyes, and many of the additives used during
the growth of nanocrystals and quantum dots. Moreover, polymers are
found widely in biology and comprise most biological macromolecules:
polypeptides, polysaccharides, and nucleic acids. Almost every drug
molecule is an organic structure. Lucky for us, it is not necessary to
take an entire year of organic chemistry to learn what you need to know
to be an effective nanoengineer. In fact, it's best not to even think of
this material as "organic chemistry." Rather, you can think of it as
*molecular structure and bonding*. It just so happens that most
molecules are made of carbon, hydrogen, nitrogen, oxygen and a few other
supporting players like sulfur and phosphorous, and thus considered
"organic."
Do you have any questions?

#### Section 2: Basic nomenclature
Just like writing in a markup language like LaTeX or HTML, one can
describe any molecule using a linear sequence of words, numbers, and
brackets. We will call this language *Organic*. It operates by the
nomenclature established by the International Union of Pure and Applied
Chemistry (IUPAC). However, by describing chemical structures only in
words, the IUPAC name gets really long even for simple compounds. In
fact, most chemists don't use IUPAC names for any but the most basic
structures (e.g., methane, ethane, propane, and butane). After all, it
is almost always easier to just draw the structure. Moreover, most
complicated structures have common names (like aspirin, ibuprofen, and
Paxlovid). Thankfully, we don't need to know very many types of
structures in this course. Let's start with the linear hydrocarbons.

### 5.2.1. Hydrocarbons: Counting to twelve in *Organic* Just like any
other language, Organic has words corresponding to numbers of carbon
atoms. So, the words for the hydrocarbons of the general formula C
$_{{n}}$ H $_{2{n}+2}$ as follows for $n$:

1.  methane

2.  ethane

3.  propane

4.  butane

5.  pentane

6.  hexane

7.  heptane

8.  octane

9.  nonane

10. decane

11. undecane

12. dodecane

If you need to count beyond 12, there is a pattern: tridecane,
tetradecane, pentadecane, hexadecane, heptadecane, octadecane,
nonadecane, and finally isocane for $n=20$.

When converting the name of molecule to its structure, we usually leave
out the carbon and hydrogen atoms. The reason is because they appear so
regularly it would be tedious if we had to keep writing them. Instead,
we just draw the bonds---the atoms are implied. A carbon atom always has
four bonds. If the bonding partners are not shown, we assume that the
remaining bonds are to hydrogen. Every vertex and terminus of the
structure signify a carbon atom. So, pentane, with the empirical formula
C $_{5}$ H $_{12}$ , has the structure shown in Figure (5.1):

(Figure 5.1) 
>>>image(pentane.png.0)

Verify that you could draw the structures of any of the hydrocarbons
with $n=1-20$.
Do you have any questions?
what are polymers?

The textbook section you're reading doesn't specifically discuss polymers. It focuses on hydrocarbons and IUPAC nomenclature. For information on polymers, you might want to check other chapters or sections of your textbook. Is there something specific about hydrocarbons you'd like to discuss?
so are they like molecules?

Yes, polymers are molecules, but very large ones. They're made up of many repeating units called monomers. The text you're reading focuses on simpler molecules like hydrocarbons. Would you like to discuss the hydrocarbon naming system mentioned in the text?

#### Section 1: Introduction
Organic molecules comprise 99% of what we mean when we say "molecules."
The ability to speak a few words of Organic---as in a language---is thus

polymers as examples of organic nanostructures (as in vaccine delivery

in a piece of plexiglass), and Chapter 7 covers some examples of
electronic polymers. For a video primer to this chapter, visit

>>>video(https://youtu.be/v_5SYuuiyK4)

all polymers (including all photoresists used in nanofabrication),

"organic."

#### Section 2: Basic nomenclature
Just like writing in a markup language like LaTeX or HTML, one can
describe any molecule using a linear sequence of words, numbers, and
brackets. We will call this language *Organic*. It operates by the
nomenclature established by the International Union of Pure and Applied
Chemistry (IUPAC). However, by describing chemical structures only in
words, the IUPAC name gets really long even for simple compounds. In
fact, most chemists don't use IUPAC names for any but the most basic
structures (e.g., methane, ethane, propane, and butane). After all, it
is almost always easier to just draw the structure. Moreover, most
complicated structures have common names (like aspirin, ibuprofen, and
Paxlovid). Thankfully, we don't need to know very many types of
structures in this course. Let's start with the linear hydrocarbons.

### 5.2.1. Hydrocarbons: Counting to twelve in *Organic* Just like any
other language, Organic has words corresponding to numbers of carbon
atoms. So, the words for the hydrocarbons of the general formula C
$_{{n}}$ H $_{2{n}+2}$ as follows for $n$:

1.  methane

2.  ethane

3.  propane

4.  butane

5.  pentane

6.  hexane

7.  heptane

8.  octane

9.  nonane

10. decane

11. undecane

12. dodecane

If you need to count beyond 12, there is a pattern: tridecane,
tetradecane, pentadecane, hexadecane, heptadecane, octadecane,
nonadecane, and finally isocane for $n=20$.

When converting the name of molecule to its structure, we usually leave
out the carbon and hydrogen atoms. The reason is because they appear so
regularly it would be tedious if we had to keep writing them. Instead,
we just draw the bonds---the atoms are implied. A carbon atom always has
four bonds. If the bonding partners are not shown, we assume that the
remaining bonds are to hydrogen. Every vertex and terminus of the
structure signify a carbon atom. So, pentane, with the empirical formula
C $_{5}$ H $_{12}$ , has the structure shown in Figure (5.1):

(Figure 5.1) 
>>>image(pentane.png.0)

Verify that you could draw the structures of any of the hydrocarbons
with $n=1-20$.
Do you have any questions?

#### Section 3: Functional groups
Molecules with carbon-containing backbones are called **organic
molecules**. The most common elements beside carbon and hydrogen
incorporated into organic molecules that occur naturally are oxygen and
nitrogen, and to a lesser extent, phosphorous (e.g., found in the
backbone of DNA) and sulfur (e.g., found in the amino acids cysteine and
methionine). Unnatural organic structures can contain many other
elements, such as chlorine (e.g., polyvinyl chloride) or bromine.

The site where non-carbon elements are incorporated into an organic
molecule is called a **functional group**. These groups are called
*functional* because they often dictate the properties---thermodynamic
properties like melting and boiling point, along with chemical
properties like reactivity---of the molecule. It is not uncommon for
molecules to have many functional groups. The most common functional
groups you will encounter are shown in Figure (5.2), below.

(Figure 5.2) 
>>>image(functional groups.png.0)

R represents any group or part of a molecule, with the expectation that
the first atom of the R group is carbon. The C=O (double bond) subunit
of acids, amides, and esters is called a **carbonyl**. All of the
functional groups in this list are polar---capable of bonding by
dipole-dipole and dipole-induced dipole forces---and alcohols, amines,
carboxylic acids, and amides are donors of hydrogen bonds. All five
structures are also capable of accepting hydrogen bonds through the lone
pairs on the oxygen atom of the carbonyl, or through the nitrogen atom
(for amines).
Do you have any questions?

#### Section 4: Chemical reactivity
In this course, we have taken a relaxed definition of the word "bond"
such that it includes van der Waals bonds and other electrostatic
interactions. In this section, we will briefly mention the types of
bonds that form in traditional chemical systems. That is, those that
involve the movement or formal sharing or transfer of electrons.

### 5.4.1. Electrostatic attraction and ionic bonding The most basic
type of bond is the one described in subsection (2.1.1). This is a
classic ionic bond between oppositely charged species that obeys
Coulomb's law of electrostatic attraction. There is no formal sharing of
electrons; they simply attract and get stuck to each other because
that's what objects with opposite charges do. The quintessential example
is the "bonding" of a sodium ion and a chloride ion to get
Na$^{+}+$Cl$^-$=NaCl. In some cases, such an interaction arises because
of a formal **electron transfer** reaction. For example, if a neutral
sodium atom (Na$^0$) came in close proximity to a neutral chlorine atom
(Cl$^0$), then an electron would jump from the sodium atom to the
chlorine atom. The sodium atom would be oxidized to Na$^+$ and the
chlorine atom would be reduced to Cl$^-$. Once formally charged in this
way, the ions would interact electrostatically.[^5.4.1]

### 5.4.2. Reactivity arising from functional groups Functional groups
react with one another by moving electrons around to form new covalent
bonds. In the zig-zag drawings, each bond represents a pair of
electrons. In covalent bonds like C-H, C-C, or C-F, one electron comes
from one atom of the bonded pair, and one electron comes from the
other.[^5.4.2] Chemical reactions are **quantum mechanical**, meaning that
the electrons occupy an **orbital** whose shape and energy level are
predicted by solutions to the Schrödinger equation or more complicated
mathematical techniques.[^5.4.3] Regardless of these complexities, the
movement of electrons can often be predicted by electrostatics. That is,
atoms bearing partial negative charges are drawn to atoms bearing
partial positive charges. A partial charge is generated any time two
atoms with unequal electronegativities are bonded to each other. In this
case, the electrons attached to the atom with the partial negative
charge---the **nucleophile**---move to bond with the atom with the
partial positive charge---the **electrophile**---to form a bond. In
Figure (5.3), below, the oxygen atom attacks the carbon atom at a
polarized C--Br bond to form an **ether bond**.

(Figure 5.3) 
>>>image(sn2.png.0)

While we often associate functional groups with the presence of
**heteroatoms**---atoms other than carbon or hydrogen---it turns out
that double and triple bonds between carbon atoms are also reactive to
form new bonds. This reactivity arises from the properties of $\pi$
bonds, which run parallel (but separated from) the $\sigma$ bond that
defines the internuclear axis (i.e., the line connecting the elements).
Such functional groups based on double and triple bonds are particularly
important for applications in nanoengineering. For example, polymers and
polymeric nanoparticles are produced by the reaction of double bonds to
form polymers, as shown in Figure (5.4), below.

(Figure 5.4) 
>>>image(polymerization.png.0)

Additionally, triple bonds (called **alkynes**) and azides (--N $_{3}$ )
form a linkage called a triazole in a copper-catalyzed reaction called a
Huisgen cycloaddition,[^5.4.4] meaning that the reaction forms a ring. This
reaction is so sure-fire, quick, and irreversible, it is one of the most
famous examples of a transformation called a **click reaction**, Figure
(5.5). This process has been used to bind proteins and drugs to
nanoparticles, nanoparticles to each other, and molecules to surfaces.
The azide-alkyne cycloaddition is not the only click reaction, but it is
the most famous, and usually the one people are talking about.

(Figure 5.5) 
>>>image(click.png.0)

If you have taken a class in organic chemistry, you probably encountered
curly arrows or "arrow-pushing mechanisms." That is, the way organic
chemists account for the movement of all of the electrons in a reaction.
In this class---and in many applications in nanoengineering---it is more
useful to think of functional groups as Lego blocks or Tetris pieces.
That is, they fit only with specific reaction partners. Just know that
electrons are never created nor destroyed in these processes, and people
actually do know how to account for all the electrons.

It is also useful to remember a few things to avoid the most common
errors when considering the products of chemical reactions. Among them:

1.  Carbon usually has four bonds, never five

2.  Oxygen has two bonds; if it has three, it gets a positive charge,
    and if it has one, it gets a negative charge

3.  Nitrogen has three bonds; if it has four, then it gets a positive
    charge

[^5.4.1]: Prior to the transfer of the electron, the neutral atoms would
    interact by London dispersion. The transfer of the electron followed
    by strong interaction by ionic bonding is called the **harpoon
    effect**.

[^5.4.2]: Recall the octet rule from high school chemistry.

[^5.4.3]: More on the Schrödinger equation to come in Chapter 8!

[^5.4.4]: You *definitely* don't need to know this name.
Do you have any questions?
what do the paranthesis looking things mean?
I'm not entirely sure which parentheses you're referring to. Could you point out a specific example from the text? That way, I can provide a more accurate explanation about their meaning or purpose.
in the diagram

The diagrams in this section don't show any parentheses. Could you clarify which specific diagram you're looking at and what part of it you're asking about? This will help me give you a more accurate answer.
the nx

I see. You're referring to the (nx) in Figure 5.4, which shows polymerization. 

The (nx) indicates that the monomer unit is repeated 'n' times in the polymer chain. 'n' represents the number of repeating units, and 'x' is typically used to denote the entire repeating unit structure.

This notation is commonly used in polymer chemistry to show that a structure repeats multiple times to form a long chain.
why is there a paranthesis denoted by it

The parentheses in (nx) are used to group the repeating unit. They indicate that everything inside the parentheses is repeated 'n' times in the polymer chain. This notation helps chemists quickly understand the polymer's structure without drawing out every single unit.
no i mean in the drawing

I apologize for the confusion. In the drawing, the parentheses-like symbols are actually brackets [ ]. These brackets in chemical structures typically indicate that the enclosed portion is repeated. They're used to show the repeating unit of the polymer chain visually, corresponding to the (nx) in the formula.
so they continue longer than what is shown?

Exactly! You've got it. The brackets in the diagram indicate that the polymer chain continues beyond what's explicitly shown. It's a way to represent that the structure repeats many times, potentially thousands or millions of times in a real polymer molecule.
